content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Jackie Roosevelt Robinson, born on January 31, 1919, in Cairo, Georgia, was a standout athlete at the University of California Los Angeles. He made history in 1947 as the first black player in Major League Baseball with the Brooklyn Dodgers. Robinson's exceptional performance earned him the National League's Rookie of the Year Award in his first season and the Most Valuable Player award in 1949. He was later inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1962. Jackie Robinson's impact extended beyond athletics, influencing civil and human rights in America. He was the first black player in Major League Baseball, gaining widespread admiration for his fortitude and integrity. By 1947, he was ranked as one of the most popular individuals in America. Robinson's significance led to his induction into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1962. Jackie Robinson's legacy extended beyond athletics as he became a prominent figure in civil rights. He was named vice president of Chock Full O' Nuts and co-founded the Freedom National Bank of Harlem. Robinson influenced political leaders and worked with various organizations to improve the lives of Americans. His principles are upheld by the Jackie Robinson Foundation, providing educational opportunities for low-income families. His achievements as an athlete, business leader, and citizen have positively impacted civil rights in the United States. The President is authorized to present a gold medal to Jackie Robinson's family in recognition of his contributions. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike the medal with suitable emblems. Duplicates in bronze may be sold to cover costs. The medals are considered national medals. Authorization of appropriations is also included. The medals struck under this Act are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code. An amount not to exceed $30,000 is authorized to pay for the cost of the medal. Amounts received from the sale of duplicate bronze medals shall be deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. Congress suggests designating a national day to recognize Jackie Robinson's accomplishments. The 108th Congress passed a bill to award a congressional gold medal posthumously to Jackie Robinson for his contributions to the nation and proposed a national day in his honor.
